qas.question: De Rerum Natura is a poem by who?
What kinf of explanation does De Rerum Natura provide for phenomena?
What kind of explanation does De Rerum Natura argue for rejecting phenomena?
Who wrote the line "Everything can touch body but body"?
Who believed space was not another kind of being?
Whose view believes that there is more than matter and void?
How many languages was De Rerum translated into?

context: Ancient Greek philosophers like Thales, Anaxagoras (ca. 500 BC – 428 BC), Epicurus and Democritus prefigure later materialists. The Latin poem De Rerum Natura by <a0_0>Lucretius<a0_0/> (ca. <b6_0>99<b6_0/> BC – ca. 55 BC) reflects the mechanistic philosophy of <b5_0>Democritus and Epicurus<b5_0/>. According to this view, all that exists is matter and void, and all phenomena result from different motions and conglomerations of base material particles called "atoms" (literally: "indivisibles"). De Rerum Natura provides <a1_0><b2_0>mechanistic explanations<b2_0/><a1_0/> for phenomena such as erosion, evaporation, wind, and sound. Famous principles like "nothing can touch body but body" first appeared in the works of <b3_0>Lucretius<b3_0/>. <b4_0>Democritus and Epicurus<b4_0/> however did not hold to a monist ontology since they held to the ontological separation of matter and space i.e. space being "another kind" of being, indicating that the definition of "materialism" is wider than given scope for in this article.
